@maialmrn @Cascadiavotes1 @KateAronoff That is also why I said we *compare* it to a right which we think is the best comparison, but we are trying to make a point about what happens when a market breaks down, so I'm not going to die on the hill of whether our turn of phrase is perfect (it's the best we could think of)

@maialmrn @Cascadiavotes1 @KateAronoff Well the paper actually doesn't say electricity is/is not a right for precisely that reason (definition of right). It's called the consequences of treating elec. *like* a right. If it actually were a de jure right (which it's not), we could discuss the value of being called such.
@srini_econ @KateAronoff Well I'm not sure what to make of the abstract being called "cursed". Not the most precise of criticisms, so its hard to respond.

@Cascadiavotes1 @KateAronoff Which way does the causality go? Is the absence of universal distribution the reason inequality is high, or is it politically hard to implement univ. transfers *because* inequality is high (convince a poor farmer to vote for you to give very scarce money to someone 200x richer)

@Cascadiavotes1 @KateAronoff We compare it to a "right" because everyone is getting away with it. If we saw utilities reliably cutting off the rich(er) [not really "rich" by western standards], I might call it an unwritten subsidy. But sure, you can pick another word if you like - "norm"/"entitlement"

@Cascadiavotes1 @KateAronoff A related problem with block rates in densely populated poor countries is there aren't enough rich people to pay. 100 people consuming little and paying nothing, produces less money for the same power than 1 poor person paying/using little and 10 others paying/using much more.

@Cascadiavotes1 @KateAronoff Maybe. Personally I *think* its tough- govts have implemented targeted transfers but rarely (ever?) universal ones. Anyway you're suggesting *higher* rates to pay for this, a reasonable idea, though I shudder to think how some people might react to *that* being in abstract :)

@Cascadiavotes1 @KateAronoff Sure you could do a universal benefit also, its a harder political sell in very poor countries with high inequality and also likely too expensive. Still, maybe its easier to implement.

@Cascadiavotes1 @KateAronoff Also why we show (Figure 6) that the majority of losses due to theft doesn't come from the poorest people but from large consumers. The *norm* of payment is universal, the *social costs* of not paying are largest when those who don't pay use a lot.

@Cascadiavotes1 @KateAronoff Yes and that's why the paper says "Subsidies on electricity are often enjoyed by consumers across the income distribution, which both makes them regressive... government might instead provide direct benefits to the poorest members of society."
